questions.question_text: In Fig. 6.13, lines AB and CD intersect at O. If ∠ AOC + ∠ BOE = 70° and ∠ BOD = 40°, find ∠ BOE and reflex ∠ COE.
In Fig. 6.14, lines XY and MN intersect at O. If ∠ POY = 90° and a : b = 2 : 3, find c.
In Fig. 6.15, ∠ PQR = ∠ PRQ, then prove that ∠ PQS = ∠ PRT.
hints: Show both angles are supplementary to equal angles

questions.question_text: In Fig. 6.16, if x + y = w + z, then prove that AOB is a line.
hints: Sum of angles around point O is 360°

questions.question_text: In Fig. 6.17, POQ is a line. Ray OR is perpendicular to line PQ. OS is another ray lying between rays OP and OR. Prove that ∠ ROS = 1/2 (∠ QOS – ∠ POS).
hints: Express angles in terms of given ones

questions.question_text: It is given that ∠ XYZ = 64° and XY is produced to point P. Draw a figure from the given information. If ray YQ bisects ∠ ZYP, find ∠ XYQ and reflex ∠ QYP.
hints: Draw extended line XY to P

questions.question_text: In Fig. 6.23, if AB || CD, CD || EF and y : z = 3 : 7, find x.
hints: Use consecutive interior angles for parallel lines
Apply ratio to find y and z
x is corresponding/alternate to sum of y and z

questions.question_text: In Fig. 6.24, if AB || CD, EF ⊥ CD and ∠ GED = 126°, find ∠ AGE, ∠ GEF and ∠ FGE.
hints: Use perpendicular to find right angles

questions.question_text: In Fig. 6.25, if PQ || ST, ∠ PQR = 110° and ∠ RST = 130°, find ∠ QRS. [Hint : Draw a line parallel to ST through point R.]
hints: Draw auxiliary parallel line through R

questions.question_text: In Fig. 6.26, if AB || CD, ∠ APQ = 50° and ∠ PRD = 127°, find x and y.
hints: Linear pair for angle adjacent to 127°
Use triangle angle sum if needed

questions.question_text: In Fig. 6.27, PQ and RS are two mirrors placed parallel to each other. An incident ray AB strikes the mirror PQ at B, the reflected ray moves along the path BC and strikes the mirror RS at C and again reflects back along CD. Prove that AB || CD.
hints: Use law of reflection (angle of incidence = angle of reflection)
Alternate interior angles formed by transversal
Show equal angles using reflection property
Apply converse of alternate angles theorem
